creator: wsmwk

content:
Installed through apt (not snap).

But I could "solve" it:

  1. Uninstall thunderbird
  2. Install thunderbird through snap
  3. Ran into error that thunderbird process is already running (but there is none). This is a known problem, because my thunderbird-profile was on an encrypted veracrypt container and snap cannot access non-home files
  4. moved thunderbird-profile to /home/.thunderbird/xyz
  5. reinstalled thunderbird through apt (removed snap version)

Thunderbird runs normally
creator: michaelkron

content:
So reinstalling using the same method helped?

FWIW https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1864589 - Severe slowdowns and blocking of the O.S. when using veracrypt 1.26.7
creator: wsmwk

content: I think all the uninstall, reinstall with snap, uninstall snap and so on had nothing to do with the problem. Moving the thunderbird-profile from veracrypt to just /home/.../.thunderbird/xyz did it
creator: michaelkron

content:
> Moving the thunderbird-profile from veracrypt to just /home/.../.thunderbird/xyz did it

Excellent. That fits then with the bug report I cited.

creator: ingela.manson

content:
IF the index is not in sync with the actual emails stored in mbox file then it may not be able to access the stored email. So if emails are still available then a folder repair should sort out that issue.

  • Right click on Folder and select 'Properties'
  • click on 'Repair Folder'
  • Click on OK

If you have an Anti-Virus and it's allowed to scan profile files and folders and it's allowed to try and Fix anything then it's possible th Anti-Virus has corrupted the file storing the emails. You see, Anti-virus products do not understand that a single text file stores alot of emails not just one bad one. Advise is to make your Thunderbird profile folders exempt from scanning OR at the very least never allow any Anti-Virus product to auto or manual fix anything it may detect in a Thunderbird profile. Anti-Virus would not effect an index file which can explain why it thinks something is there when it is not.

content:
Interesting result:

  1. Numbered list item Made a new folder
  2. Selected all messages in old folder
  3. Dragged to new folder
  4. Old folder does not display any messages but says 13 unread of 629

Odd. Went to check directory of local folders to see if it was now empty. It was not, with a .sbd folder under it.

Solution: Unread message and total message count for a folder appears to display the count of messages in that folder PLUS any subfolders (?). So when a top-level local folder is "Favorited" and only favorited folders are displayed in the view, all subfolders (and unread messages) are hidden from the user. So change view to "all" to see all folders.

To ascertain whether this is a TB problem, it is best to start the computer (Windows?) in Safe Mode with Networking and see if the problem persists. This is a diagnostic only. If TB works normally then the problem will be a conflict of some sort.

content: Okay. So your computer is locking without TB running? I'm not sure if this is a computer or mobile problem but, if a computer... You can see what programs are installed at Start Up by using Ctrl+Shift+Esc and click on the 'Start-Up Apps' icon on the left. You could also start your computer in Safe Mode with Networking support and turn programs on one-by-one to see what effect they have on your computer's stability.

creator: allan63

content:
This will have to wait for someone more experienced. However, I'd be interested to know what TB is doing.

1. Keep TB open

2. Do you know where your profiles are? In Windows, they would be at: C:\Users\[User]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release then go to Mail and find/open the account you use Find the name of the folder in which the emails are. There will be 2 folders, one with the extension .msf. IGNORE this one. Write down the file size of the other. This contains all the data of your emails. Keep this window open.

3. Close TB and relaunch it.

4. Has the file size under 2 changed?

The reason I'm asking you to do this is for my own information - this happens to a few users. If TB is removing all the bodies from your emails then that file should reduce in size to almost zero after closing and re-opening as it removed data. If it stays the same (and yet TB starts to sync all over again) then that would be a different problem.

I have no idea how to solve either but it would be good to know just what TB is doing.
creator: frisée

See pic attached of some of the folders (there are other multiple folders for other mail accounts)

I wonder if these are old and can be deleted?

I closed TB and restarted, and the file size had changed, but very marginally.

content:
So, have you found the file and does as I asked so that we can determine whether TB is deleting data or simply not finding it?

If you intend trying to do something to the other gmail folders, then shut TB down first. Then drag the folders that you think are obsolete to somewhere safe. Keeping the window open, relaunch TB and see how it operates. See if TB has repopulated the open window with any other folders.

And keep the removed files for a week or so until you are absolutely sure there is no negative impact on the program.
creator: frisée

content: Please provide specific details on how you moved the info from one computer to another. And what was intended when you typed v5ipggs? Thanks.
creator: davidsk

content: The v5lpggs. default file is what you get when you export from thunderbird. Then you transfer it to the new computer and import it and the emails to thunderbird. It is suppose to bring up all your email accounts and emails that you had in the old computer. It put this info into thunderbird but the accounts aren't working. I need help in getting thunderbird to work the right way.
creator: nancy.wheeler

content:
Is the old computer still available? If so, follow these steps: here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

Using the tools>export has proved problematic and the above steps always work. If the old computer is gone, I suggest unzipping the file you have and post a screenshot from Windows File Explorer on what is there that didn't get moved.
creator: davidsk

content: Are you trying to set up a POP or IMAP account? When you say Spectrum is to forward your mail, that would imply that one email account is sending emails received to another email account. Is this what you are trying to achieve? Have you been using the connection settings on the web page published by Spectrum?
creator: frisée

content: It is IMAP. Yes, I get email from Spectrum. but I don't want to go through the steps of signing in every time I want to check my emails. I want to forward this email to Thunderbird if I can have it on desktop as my email client. I have followed all Spectrum's directions and nothing has worked. When I test the settings, I get a message about a connection not being able to get through. I never had email issues when using outlook classic...but then Microsoft shut it down without warning and a lot is messed up.
creator: dvr8man-

content:
Having Thunderbird forward emails to a different email address would be created by setting up a filter by accessing the Hamburger icon (top right)/Tools/Message Filters. That's for future reference...

...but I understand you to say that you want Spectrum to send emails received to Thunderbird. So, that would have to be set up in Spectrum. But that would also be a POP account, not an IMAP one.

IMAP mirrors the contents of the Email Server while a POP account downloads the emails from the Server.

So, I'm a little confused as to what you're trying to achieve. It doesn't take much to confuse me, either...
creator: frisée

content:
I would never recommend overriding the Security Certificate warning - that's something that the Email provider would need to sort out. It's there to protect your security and the integrity of your system. However, do I understand correctly that you have allowed access for TB?

What error messages are you getting when it fails to send and/or receive email?
creator: frisée

content:
Thank you very much for your reply and pardon my delayed response. I have continued to struggle with this today. I am now able to send emails from my account only if I remove the outgoing connection security and have an authentication method of "password, transmit insecurely" set up in the SMPT account settings.

Nothing coming in on the incoming side. TB is currently asking for a password for the IMAP server account. I have entered my current webmail password and it does fails. (It works for my webmail). I looked back at other passwords I have used in the past for Grande Communications and tried them as well. Still fails as I would think it should. TB now is seeing the IMAP server which it was not doing yesterday. The connection times out since the password is not being accepted.

I think I need to have a discussion with a representative from Grande Communications about their security certificate situation at this point and to get my password situation understood. I am not fond of having the settings mentioned above for the SMPT server which I assume is mostly attributed to the Security Certificate situation with Grande Communications.

Thank you again for your time and your guidance. Mike

Inoltre, Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
